    Head J (cont.) -

     The Chairman: Head J - Ministry of Community Development. Amendment No. (2), Dr Ho.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Bishan-Toa Payoh) : Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head J of the Main Estimates be reduced by $10 in respect of Code JD 1500.

    Sir, MCD's Family Support Division administers various schemes to help low income and destitute individuals and families. While most low-income families are aware of the public assistance scheme, many are still not aware of the other forms of assistance being given to the public, schemes such as the Small Families Improvement Scheme, interest free loan scheme for skills training and upgrading, or even the Rent and Utilities Assistance Scheme, or outreach programme for low-income families.

    The Report of the Cost Review Committee has highlighted the need to reach out to low-income families. The National Survey of Senior Citizens 1995 also indicated a lack of awareness of community-based services. Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what measures will be taken to publicise these schemes so that those who really need them can have access to their assistance.

    Sir, I would also like to make some suggestions in this area. Many of our poorer citizens still cannot afford to buy newspapers. They often come to the community clubs to read them. MCD could perhaps train the community club staff to help explain the various assistance schemes. Simple leaflets can also be

Column: 1312

placed at the community clubs for distribution to hardship families. MCD and HDB are now refurbishing 1-room apartments for senior citizens. In these refurbished apartments, VWOs could set up an office with full-time staff to look after the senior citizens. VWOs and their staf should be properly trained to advise on the various assistance schemes as they are usually the first-line of assistance. MCD's Homepage should also be updated regularly with the various assistance schemes so that the community clubs and the VWOs can get immediate updates.

    In such assistance programmes, Sir, I understand some means test is always applied. There is a general perception that the means test is very stringent and is difficult to qualify for the assistance and the application process requires many forms to be filled. May I ask the Minister what measures would be taken to correct these perceptions and what measures would be taken to simplify the application process?

    Sir, public assistance rates were last revised in May 1995. In today's living standards, these rates need to be revised. May I ask the Minister when will he consider an increase in the public assistance rates?

     The Chairman: Prof. Low is not here. Dr Lily Neo.

     Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, there are presently 434 childcare centres in Singapore, each one professionally run and giving the sort of care that allows some women to go out to work in peace and some women to even contemplate looking for work.

    These centres are to be praised for better education to the young and for better integration among the children. However, there is a need for more childcare centres. It has been estimated that we will require a further 2,000 places each year in the next three years. This would mean adding more centres each year.

    My question, Sir, is whether we should not now aim to have new centres better located and soon to be renovated ones

Column: 1313

decentralised and relocated. By this, I mean each centre could be of a smaller scale and is to be within short walking distance from the homes of the children. I feel that neighbourliness and social integration among the residents can come to play more significantly if residents from the nearby blocks can have a share and care attitude for each other. A grandparent or even a neighbour can conveniently mind the child should the need arise. Thus, would the Minister consider decentralising and having more smaller-scale but precinct-located childcare centres?

    The inability to entrust their young children to someone somewhere is a likely reason for working women to avoid early motherhood and more children. The majority of childcare centres have two years of age as a minimum acceptance age. Therefore, would the Minister also consider having centres that accept children less than two years of age?

     Dr Yaacob Ibrahim (Jalan Besar): My colleague, Dr Lily Neo, has just spoken about the need for us to ensure good quality childcare facilities, increasing number of childcare centres and new centres which are a bit more diversified. I support her position on this, Sir.

    However, my concern is on the role of childcare centre in the raising of our young. The Government in its attempt to attract more women back into the workforce has decided to give subsidies to women who need to leave their children at childcare centres. Women who work pay less as compared to women who do not work.

    Sir, I believe that women who are housewives also do work. In fact, the work they do can sometimes be more demanding than work done by some working women. Their contribution to the raising of children is equally important for this country as it is also for those women who contribute by working. So why do we treat women who stay at home differently?

Column: 1314



    I agree with the need to attract our women back to the workforce. I am not so sure whether if the subsidy is not given, these women will not go back to work. But since it is already given to working women, why not consider extending it in some form to all women. I think it is not right to suggest that non-working women have more time on their hands and can therefore raise children without the need for childcare facilities. The family structure today has changed. Extended families which provide child-raising support through grandparents are not as common as before. In fact, the Minister for National Development, Mr Lim Hng Kiang, has mentioned this trend in relation to the lack of popularity of public housing type designed to attract extended families. The grandparents of tomorrow may not want to play the same role as grandparents did when we were growing up. Tomorrow's grandparents will be more educated and may not be willing to spend their twilight years helping to raise their grandchildren. Furthermore, since most people are having children later in life, they may be physically unable to help out in the raising of grandchildren.

    Nuclear families have become common place. Usually, the wife is left all alone to care for the house and to manage the kids during the day. This can be very demanding. I have seen many cases of women who use part-time childcare facilities to free up time to attend to household chores, to study, to do freelance work or even community service. Many of these women also use part-time childcare facilities as they want to expose their children to an unstructured learning environment and provide them with an opportunity to socialise with other children.

    Sir, I would therefore urge MCD to reconsider their position on this.

     Dr Lily Neo: Sir, at the moment, there are 107 before-and-after school care (BASC) centres. I believe we do require only 60 more of them. Sir, I feel that there is an urgent need for us to have these centres set up as soon as possible to make up for the shortfall.

Column: 1315



    Whether women continue working is frequently based on whether they can leave their children somewhere safely. BASC gives peace of mind to such parents who, while they work, know that their children will be fed, supervised and encouraged to make proper use of their time both at homework and at recreation.

    We do want to increase our workforce. BASC centres, in similar ways as childcare centres, can entice more parents contemplating looking for jobs. These parents, becoming economically useful, will definitely benefit themselves, their families and the country.

    Added on to these factors, the noticeable and increasing trend towards delinquency and towards children going astray, only to be recruited into gangs, is disturbing. Our children are extremely vulnerable during their tender years and they can easily adopt unhealthy habits and wrong attitudes if exposed to wrong company. We have to prevent this and before-and-after school care centres can be one of the avenues we can make use.

    Sir, does the Ministry have plans to set up more BASC centres or to offer extra incentives to schools and grassroots organisations to set up these centres? May I also urge the Ministry to please consider having these centres built at an increased rate?

     Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, the before-and-after school care (BASC) centre was one of the key recommendations of the IMC. It was recognised then that for low-income families where both parents need to go to work, some form of care arrangement is needed for their school-going children, especially the young.

    The BASC plays an important role in the care of many children. Therefore, services in the BASC must be maintained at a high standard of quality. I have been made to understand that like kindergartens and other care facilities, the BASC faces similar problems of high staff turnover and of not being able to attract good quality staff. Maybe the Minister can enlighten us on this?

Column: 1316



    Sir, the BASC was meant to help latchkey kids stay out of trouble. After school, these kids would proceed to these centres where activities are planned for them. I understand a tutor is usually around to assist them with their homework. My question, Sir, is whether this programme has been effective in reducing the problem of juvenile delinquency. Is MCD tracking the performance and behaviour of these kids? If so, perhaps MCD can share its observations with the House. I believe this is important as I understand that MCD intends to extend BASC to secondary school-going children. Will the BASC model used thus far be effective for secondary school children? It has also come to my attention that some parents view the BASC as a cheaper form of tuition. This is not right. Is anything being done to correct this image of the BASC among some parents? Parents of secondary school-going kids are more likely to view BASCs in this manner given the pressures of secondary school children.

    The BASC does not discriminate between low and middle or upper income families. We know there are many dual income families who would send their kids to BASC centres. The original intent of BASC was to help low-income families. Perhaps MCD may want to consider a graded fee structure where middle and upper income families who use these centres pay more than the low-income families. The Government subsidy must be given to the families most in need.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, currently, there are reports of boys escaping from the Boys' Home. According to the Straits Times' report, the Home experienced two to three break-out attempts every month. I also have knowledge of a case in which a group of 17 boys escaped. The incident happened on 27th December 1996. The boys escaped through a hole opening which was cut by using grass cutting shears. They were assigned to undertake gardening task.

    Sir, the Boys' Home is an important social institution as it is tasked to rehabilitate young crime offenders as

Column: 1317

sentenced by the Juvenile Court. If the Boys' Home fails to rehabilitate them properly and to help them turn into a new leaf to become a useful member of the society, I am afraid when these young offenders grow up, we may have more criminal cases to deal with.

    Sir, I have the following questions for the Minister. (1) What is the underlying cause of such frequent outbreaks of boys attempting to escape from the Home? (2) What is the supervisor and inmate ratio and whether this ratio in the opinion of the Minister is an effective ratio? (3) What is the rehabilitation programme of the Home and its daily routine programme? (4) How many inmates are charged again in court during their stay in the Home for offences committed in the Boys' Home, such as escaping from the Home, etc?
12.45 pm

     The Minister for Community Development (Mr Abdullah Tarmugi): Sir, I would like, first, to take Dr Ho Tat Kin's question on the public assistance scheme, and also his views on measures to publicise help schemes to the potential recipients.

    Sir, my Ministry cannot agree more with Dr Ho on the need for families in distress or families who need help to know the kind of help that they can get in the community. And they should be helped to gain access to such help institutions in the community.

    Creating awareness of this network of services in the community is not easy. The normal publicity channels, eg, the media, are not enough. Because my experience, as a journalist, is that we can have news in the media, we can have items in the newspapers, but somehow people do not read them. Even people who can read do not know about many happenings. So it is a difficult exercise. A multi-pronged approach is needed to disseminate the kind of information we have on these help institutions in the community.

Column: 1318



    The usual avenues like brochures, information booklets and directories are being compiled by my Ministry, and also the National Council of Social Service (NCSS). These information materials are given to community centres, the FSCs, grassroots organisations and the VWOs.

    In January this year, for example, the Ministry published a directory of services to help low-income families. This is a compendium of all the services that are available in Singapore, and this is disseminated very widely. If the Member wishes to have copies, we can certainly provide him with some. The directory will serve as a quick reference guide to the public, and also to all VWOs on the service providers who are in the community.

    We also hold talks and briefings for voluntary welfare organisations, schools, unions and grassroots organisations on the kind of help the Ministry is dispensing, and also what are available in the community and the set-up of the VWOs.

    Recognising that low-income families have somehow special difficulty in getting at these usual channels of publicity, my Ministry is also working with the two CDCs that have been set up on an outreach programme. This involves knocking door to door and to tell the people, especially those in the 1- and 2-room rental flats, about the services that are available and that could be of help to them. We hope this would increase the reach to people who really need such assistance.

    Coming to the public assistance (PA) allowance, the Member asked about the means test that has to be done, and also the forms that have to be filled. Sir, different services would need different criteria. There are different criteria that have to be fulfilled, and they have different objectives also. To get information from the applicants, we have to have forms as some information have to be collected from them. And we try to make it as simple as possible. We try to collect the minimum that is needed for us to be able to assess or to evaluate the applications.

Column: 1319



    When there are instances of people who need help in filling up the forms, there are VWOs and FSCs who are willing to help out with filling up the forms. They are quite used to the format of the forms anyway.

    Dr Ho also asked about the increase of the PA rates. I do not know whether the Member is aware that we increase the rates once in every two years. It is correct, as he pointed out, that the last time we increased the rates was in 1995, and indeed we have raised the rates this year. In fact, it was increased in May this year. By the way, it was publicised in the newspapers. The increase in the rates is indexed to the CPI.

    Sir, Dr Lily Neo asked whether we could build more child care centres, and also whether these centres could be more conveniently located for the convenience of families needing them. As at July 1997, as I have mentioned yesterday, there are 442 child care centres run by both profit and non-profit organisations. We plan to have about 550 centres by the year 2000. We monitor the use of these child care centres periodically and if we need to increase the number, we would do so.

    In planning for these child care centres, we do take into account the demand. We also take into account the convenience in terms of location and we also take into account the availability of the supporting resources in the area. So they are not centralised in that sense, but in fact located within the HDB heartland itself, in the HDB estates. So they are as convenient as possible.

    But to make the catchment smaller, Sir, would mean that we would need smaller centres, and the financial viability of these centres would come into question. There are economies of scale which can be gained from centres which have large enrolment. Our assessment is that a centre of about 70-100 children is about the most economical size of a child care centre, as this would maximize the supervisory staff and also the space that is available.

    In principle, we have no objection to smaller size child care centres, and also to

Column: 1320

have HDB estates being peppered with child care centres. Much depends on the operators and on their assessment of the viability of their centres.

    With regard to whether child care centres would accept children below two years old, child care centres, in fact, are allowed to take in children right down to two months old. However, the child care centres usually take in children from 1 1/2 years and above, because they do not find it economically viable to take in infants or toddlers below 1 1/2 years old. We had centres which used to take in very young children, and this group of centres, I am afraid, have folded up, because they found that they were not economically viable.

    The solution for such young children is the family day-care programme, where children can be looked after in the home environment. In other words, children are fostered out to baby sitters who have their own homes, and they can be taken care of in a home environment, and not in an institutional environment. My Ministry, in fact, is looking into encouraging the development of more family day-care centre services. We used to have it last time, but somehow it had to be stopped because of some problems. But the system is workable, and we will be relooking into the system to see whethere there are ways to improve it, and to see whether there are ways we could encourage VWOs or foster mothers to take up the programme.

    Dr Yaacob is concerned with child care needs. He asked whether we could subsidise non-working mothers to send their children to child care centres. First, I would like to reiterate MCD's stand that we think both working women and non-working women contribute to society. We are not saying that working women contribute more than non-working women. Let us have this straight. Having said that, the Government has no plans, as of now at least, to extend these subsidies to non-working women.

    The reason is this. The objective of the subsidies, which are $150 and $75 if it is part-time, is to encourage women to go

Column: 1321

out to work, which means that the subsidy would only be available to working women who send their children to child care centres. As such, the subsidy for child care centres will be available to them. Subsidies for BASCs are also available to working women only.

    Where children can be taken care of in the home environment, preferably with a mother around, we would always encourage that. To extend this subsidy to all non-working mothers, I am afraid, would create an artificial demand. But if we limit it to only a certain proportion of non-working women, then we have to set up criteria, we have to decide who can get this subsidy and who would not. Quite apart from these difficulties, I think the basic principle is that we would rather that the child be taken care of by the mother in the home. If that can happen and if that can be done, we would encourage that.

    But for non-working mothers who have genuine problems, which means that they have to put their children in child care centres, we would find alternative ways of helping them. There are, in fact, VWOs who help them out in terms of helping to pay for the fees of the child care centres.

    The Member also mentioned that some women use the part-time child care centres to expose their children to an unstructured learning and for socialisation purposes. The Member may wish to know that besides child care centres, there are also other pre-school facilities such as kindergartens, nursery programmes and play schools which provide similar opportunities. These are programmes between 2-4 hours which are short enough to be considered as part-time by the parents. So non-working mothers do not need full-time child care facilities. They can make use of these alternative child care facilities to expose their children to this socialising process.

    Dr Lily Neo asked whether the Government could set up more before-and-after-school-care (BASC) centres and offer extra incentives to schools so that they can set up these centres. As at 1st July

Column: 1322

1997, there are 67 non-profit BASCs, including 30 BASCs which are run by commercial operators. We have a total of about 107 BASCs. We intend to increase the non-profit BASCs from 67 to 170 by the year 2000. Indeed, this is more than what the Member has asked for. She has asked for 60 more.

    With regard to incentives, with effect from December 1996, Government funding has been provided to non-profit organisations to set up BASCs, including grassroots organisations. The financial help comprises up to 90% of capital cost for conversion or renovation of the premises, up to 90% of capital cost of purchase of furnishings and equipment, and also Government subsidy to assist organisations in the initial stages of their operation because in the beginning they may run a loss. So Government subsidises them for a while. There are also fee-subsidies to help low income families.
1.00 pm

    For school BASC, Sir, the Government also provides financial assistance in that if there are no premises to run these BASCs, my Ministry will provide containers for them to use for such purposes.

    On the speed of development of BASCs, my Ministry indeed is very conscious of the need to increase the number of BASCs because of the problems that are around and we will be working closely with HDB on the identification of sites for the BASC centres. But there are some difficulties here because we have constraints. As has also been mentioned yesterday, there would be some problems in getting the manpower for these BASCs, but we will assist and try.

    Dr Yaacob asked why there was a high turnover of staff in BASCs and some parents treating BASC as tuition centres. Sir, staff turnover is not a new issue, as has been mentioned by the Member himself. It happens in childcare centres. Indeed, it happens in a lot of other institutions and organisations, especially in a very tight labour market like ours. Yesterday, I did say that the demand for

Column: 1323

social workers or for people who could do social work and community service is increasing and they are also competing for such workers. So the high turnover is nothing new actually in that sense. We will be monitoring the situation and try and find ways of improving the manpower situation.

    With regard to standards, the Member may wish to know that we have guidelines on how BASCs ought to be run, the ratio of supervisors and clients, the size and what kind of facilities ought to be provided to the boys there. So there are standards. Of course, you can argue whether these standards are enough, but again, my officers will be monitoring the situation and, if need be, we will tighten up the standards to ensure that the quality is maintained.

    As to whether we have tracked the performance of BASCs, I am afraid we were actively just promoting BASCs only last year. So I think it is a bit too soon to see both the effect of BASCs and also the performance of the BASCs themselves. But if I can here sound a note of caution: the BASC is not a panacea for the various problems of our youths and also to reduce the incidence of juvenile delinquency, but I think it is one measure which we could try, apart from other measures that are being put in place.

    The Member also mentioned that some parents treat BASCs as tuition centres This is understandable because BASC is a concept that is being promoted widely and it is still new. So parents are still confused between the actual role of BASC and tuition centres. The problem is that being before-and-after school centres, students who go there sometimes do their homework and study, and some supervisors supervise their studies and where it is possible sometimes they give tips or advice on their lessons. But this is not tuition per se. So I hope parents would understand the actual role of BASCs. They should not expect BASCs to operate as tuition centres and expect the children coming out from BASCs to be properly tuitioned and doing better in school.

Column: 1324



    Mr Low Thia Khiang asked about the underlying causes of escape from the Boys' Home. There are many causes why inmates escape from Boys' Home. Sometimes they feel they are bullied or exposed or they have to undergo a harsh regimen. So indeed there are many reasons for people who want to escape. If he is talking of escaping or abscondment from the Boys' Home, the actual number of people who abscond from the home itself is very small. For example, in the first six months of this year, out of 16 abscondment, only one actually absconded from the home. The other 15 absconded when they were outside the home. In other words, when they were going to school or when they have to go out to seek medical treatment or when they go for outings, and things like that. So they do not abscond from the home itself, as it were. They abscond when they were outside the home, although they are inmates of the home. I do not know whether the statistics which were quoted by Mr Low have this differentiation between those who abscond from the home and those who abscond outside the home.

    As for the rehabilitation programme, I am afraid I cannot give him the details now. If he wishes, I could send him the details of the rehabilitation programme of the Boys' Home.

    His last question is whether inmates are charged in court for offences committed inside the home. If it is a fighting offence, for example, there would be an internal investigation. If police help is required, they are called in and if they have to be charged in court they would be charged in court. The example is the latest incident. Late last month an inmate hit one of the supervisors with a brick from behind and the matter is still under investigation. If the police finds that the boy could be charged, and AG's advice is that the boy could be charged, then he would be charged. So it depends on what kind of offence.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: What is the actual number?

Column: 1325



     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: I am afraid I cannot again give you the actual number of cases now. But I can give you the number of cases later if you want.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: What about the ratio of supervisors?

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: I am afraid, Sir, I also do not have it available here. Again, I could give the Member the details of the ratio of supervisors to inmates later.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin: Sir, I thank the Minister for his clarification and beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

     Dr Lily Neo: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head J of the Development Estimates be reduced by $10 in respect of Code JD 5100.

    Sir, the community has gained in many areas through MCD. As we are one of the fastest-aging nations, I am glad that MCD has done a lot for the care of our elderly and I am also glad that the Finance Minister has made allocation towards the needs of the elderly. When we were talking about merger between Singapore and Malaysia, this issue was already debated and discussed very widely. Now the "Plen" is saying that the activity space for Singapore is very narrow and Singapore will face problems in the future. What does he mean by all this? Over the past 30 years, the "Plen" has never taken part in the nation building of Singapore, neither has he been to Singapore at all. But he chose to speak in this manner to a Malaysian newspaper at this time. Is he not trying to shake our confidence, and to dampen the morale of Singaporeans? I would like to ask him this question. What he said has given the people the impression that he is the Rip Van Winkle living in the world of more than 30 years ago.

    The fact is Singapore is now in a better condition to survive more than 30 years ago. Now, we have a better economic foundation. We have more national reserves. We have a good political system and we also have a strong modernised

Column: 1399

defence capability. And more importantly, the quality of our people, our educational level and our skill level are much better than those of 30 years ago. In other words, our competitiveness is much better now than before. In the whole region, we can see from the situation prevailing now that it augurs well and we should be optimistic. But it does not mean that there are no potential dangers. Whatever it is, we are much better off now than 30 years ago. We should work hard and progress, scale new heights.
5.15 pm

    Although the talk of Mr Fang Chuang Pi, the "Plen", has not stirred any reaction here, I am personally reminded of the importance of our National Education, for two reasons. I think it is important that we should strengthen the national consciousness of our people, so that they will not be misled by this kind of startling remarks.

    Secondly, we must also take preventive measures to ensure that people living a good life will not become soft, and forget the past deeds of our pioneering forefathers. So it is necessary to educate our young people to understand and know the way to nation building and to understand how we have survived.

    Sir, I would therefore like to ask the Minister for Education whether he will consider including all these points in the curriculum of the proposed National Education programme.

Column: 1400

parcel of the country. Under the Constitution, he has the right as a citizen and is protected by the Constitution. He should defend his rights and defend the nation when we face external threats. Although understanding history is important for our citizens, to understand the rights of citizens is equally necessary. Therefore, National Education should enable students to understand what kind of rights every Singapore citizen has.

     The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): Sir, first of all, I would like to thank Members for the very good suggestions that have been brought up and for their interest in education. I would like to address thinking schools first. Mr Loh Meng See, Mr Peh Chin Hua, Mr Iswaran, Dr Tan Boon Wan, Mr Lim Swee Say and Mr Hawazi Daipi have brought up very good suggestions. Rather than answer to each of them specifically, I think it may be more useful if I say something about how we are going to implement all these programmes in our schools to put them altogether.

    Our education system is fundamentally a good one. Our students have done well. Our teachers, schools and educational institutions have done well. The evidence of this can be seen from the achievements of our students in the various examinations - the high percentage of our students who now make it to our institutes of higher learning, and high standards in mathematics and science that have been attained by our students as demonstrated in the 3rd International Mathematics and Science Study. We have done well because of the many changes and the important policies that have been

Column: 1401

put in place in our education system over the last 5-10 years. We are reaping the fruits of these changes today, as education is a very long-term process. But we can reach higher and we can do better, and the changes that we are putting in place in our education system now are meant to see us through into the next century.

    The Ministry of Education has made several announcements in the past half year. These are major programmes and major changes, and I can understand if teachers and parents have a certain amount of anxiety about how all these things are going to come together. I would like to take this opportunity to place these various programmes and changes in perspective to show how these major initiatives, these various plans, draw together: National Education, information technology, creative thinking, as well as administrative excellence in our schools.

    The goal that we are reaching for is `thinking schools'. This encapsulates our vision for the schools of the 21st century. This is a concept that Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong spoke about during the Thinking Conference in June this year when he put forward his vision for `Thinking Schools and a Learning Nation'.

    While the education system has undergone changes in the past and produced commendable results, we cannot rest on our laurels. We need to be geared for continuing change to meet the needs of the 21st century. The world we are living in is changing, and our education system must change to keep pace. The body of human knowledge is growing day by day, and the discovery of new knowledge continues. Our education system has to cope with this explosion of knowledge. And the solution, as has been pointed out by several Members today, does not lie in simply adding more to the curriculum with each passing year. We have to adopt a different strategy to teach our students, our young generation, how to acquire knowledge as more knowledge is discovered in the future.

Column: 1402



    There are changes in the workplace, in the nature of jobs, in the skills required, and we must continually seek new knowledge and new skills to transition to higher level jobs. There are new techniques and innovations in education. Mr Lim Swee Say has spoken about how computers would be used in schools. If you look back at our schools and see the sort of things that we have been using, we have transitioned from blackboard and chalk to OHPs and transparencies, even educational television.

    There is not much difference in the pedagogical style. Basically, the students are there. They are receiving lessons from the teacher. But with information technology, the Internet, there will be a revolution. There can be different ways of interactivity, different ways for students to access knowledge, different ways of combining students together in different classes, different schools, different places in the world, to learn together, to share together. And the changes will not be once off. They will come wave upon wave, as the power of computers and networks continues to increase. And this will have ramifications not only on teaching but perhaps in the structure of our schools in future. We are talking about virtual schools - that will take some time to come - but there will certainly be applications for people already in the workforce, for example.

    There will be different assessment systems. The scholastic aptitude tests in the United States today are taken by computer, I think, from this year, and this will mean a different way of assessing people - adaptively. Everyone is grappling with this and no one quite knows the answer yet. We also have to feel our way forward.

    Our population and our society is changing. There is a new generation, new influences, TV, travel. Their frame of reference and mindset is changing. We need to continue to find new ways of engaging and exciting our young people to discover and learn in schools. And we must also make sure, at the same time, that they remain rooted in Singapore. Our young people need values and a sense of

Column: 1403

belonging. They need cultural and societal ballast so that they will not capsize or lose their way in this bewildering sea of contesting ideas.

    We need to strengthen our cohesion as a people and work together for a better life for all Singaporeans. That is why National Education is such an important element in our thinking schools.

    We also need a new focus on creativity and innovation, to be geared to change in our schools. We cannot produce adaptable, innovative and creative students unless we have adaptable, creative and innovative teachers and schools.

    The pace of change has quickened. In the past, the way that we have managed change in the Ministry of Education is rather top down. Ideas are tossed up. They are discussed at meetings. We consider them. We think about it, write a few papers, get it approved. We pilot it in a few schools first. Try it out for a year or two. We spread it to more. Then we spread it to all the schools. This takes many years for any change to come through our school system.

    We must encourage innovation and thinking in the schools, so that many different ideas and approaches can be tried at the same time. And good ideas should be shared and spread between schools and multiplied quickly.

    However, we must remember what are the strengths of our education system. We must retain control of a few key areas, and this also has been touched by a number of Members today. We need to maintain our national curriculum and high national standards that we have. This will ensure that the rigour and the discipline in our education system is retained. And that what our students learn meets our educational objectives and standards are maintained. This is very important. Otherwise, at the end of the day, the certificate that our students receive may be wrapped up in a nice red tube, but it is meaningless, unless the standards and the quality are maintained. There must be benchmarks which our schools and our students are expected to achieve.

Column: 1404



    Other countries that do not have such standards are moving towards them. The UK, for example, has reintroduced a national curriculum for most subjects across all levels and instituted national standard tests for pupils at ages 7, 11, 14 and 16. I was in the US recently, and in the US, President Clinton and Secretary Riley, whom I also met there, are pushing hard for national standards. But in the US, it is difficult for them to push this through because the Federal Government has no direct authority over education, and they have to persuade states to come on board to adopt national standards voluntarily.

    But these two countries, among others, have studied the results of the 3rd International Mathematics and Science Study and realise that they cannot improve unless they push for high standards. We need to keep these aspects of our education system, the rigour and the discipline in our education system, so that we will always have a system that sets high standards, demands high standards from our schools, our teachers and our students and, consequently, will produce the high standards and the results that we want for our children.

    But within these boundaries, I am prepared to consider new ideas, fresh ideas on how to achieve high standards in our education system and to meet our educational objectives. We will not change precipitously, because we have a good education system and I am in no hurry to dismantle it. But we need to encourage ideas and innovations on how to achieve our goals. We will devolve more powers to make decisions, to decide on educational strategies for achieving our educational objectives, to make decisions on the use of resources and on personnel and financial matters. We want to get a better match between the authority to make decisions on the use of resources and the responsibility for achieving educational outcomes, the responsibility for achieving results.

    These are the broad challenges that our thinking schools must meet. What is a thinking school? The foremost prerequisite of a thinking school is that it

Column: 1405

must itself be a learning organisation. A mindset of continual change must pervade each and every member of staff. A culture of continual improvement must permeate the entire school.
5.30 pm

    The key to any learning organisation is people. As exemplars of the spirit of lifelong learning, every teacher has to be a continual learner himself, seeking constantly to upgrade his instructional competencies. As professional practitioners, every teacher must keep abreast of the latest in educational research. Every teacher must innovate and adapt classroom practices and keep up with the advances in his own subject. An attitude of active on-going learning is crucial for every teacher and they are ultimately responsible for motivating and realising their own professional development. This is not change for the sake of change. What teachers must strive for is change that is carefully thought through based on new but sound principles and test them, expand them and improve on them. This is the continuing professional challenge that should keep our teachers excited and motivated about their job for 5, 10, 20, 30, 40 years in their teaching career. He has to go on creating and innovating, modifying and adapting.

    I would like to say something here about the role of teachers. I have heard a number of Members here today speak about teachers as facilitators. Yes, teachers are facilitators, but this is a term which is too neutral for my liking. A "facilitator" suggests that he just allows students to learn. Our principals and teachers are the heart and soul of our education system. Principals and teachers make a difference to what our students learn, their motivation level, how they learn. Principals and teachers are meant to have an effect on their students. They cannot merely be neutral facilitators. I think that is much too neutral a term. They provide the motivation, the inspiration, sometimes the extra push to get the students going so that they can achieve something beyond what even the

Column: 1406

students themselves thought they could achieve. This is the role of teachers and principals, not merely to facilitate the students to do whatever it is that the students want or like to do.

    All this sounds like a tall order. Indeed it would be a tall order, if teachers have to work alone. The results of solitary effort will be subject to the limits of one's own creativity. One of the catalysts of creativity is bouncing ideas off one another, allowing other people's ideas to trigger one's own. Therefore, teachers will have to work together. Teachers within their subjects and departments will be encouraged to generate and share ideas about how best to motivate their pupils and deliver difficult concepts and skills. A collective effort of teachers in schools must be harnessed to identify bottlenecks to work flow and hindrances to providing quality education.

    The Ministry is committed and will provide every support for teachers and schools. We have a number of programmes to help prepare our teachers for some of these changes that are coming. I agree with Mr Lim that if you just introduce computers in the schools and do not train the teachers properly, nothing will happen, or the wrong things may happen. So a large part of the resources that we are allocating for the IT Master Plan goes into the training of teachers. It is not just the training of teachers to use particular software packages, but the training of teachers to use computers in the teaching environment to teach the subjects that they are teaching.

    To help prepare our teachers, our goal is for every teacher to have at least 100 hours of training per year by the year 2000. The Ministry is also committed to providing teachers a more conducive working environment. This will range from things like better staff rooms to better working conditions in general. We want to give them the resources to do their jobs well.

    More importantly, the Ministry recognises that the workload of our teachers is very high and we are taking steps to try

Column: 1407

to ease the workload of our teachers. There is no single magic bullet solution for this. This will come partly through the use of technology, partly through providing a comprehensive range of administrative and other teacher supports and partly through a review of the curriculum. Most importantly, if we are able to sustain the recruitment of teachers over a number of years, we will be able to post more teachers to schools in the coming years. We recruited 1,900 teachers last year, the best for many years. This year the recruitment rate looks good. We should come close to what we did last year. If we can sustain this over a number of years, we will be better off.

    The aim is to give teachers space to reflect and time to think so that they can devote more time and energy to continually strive for professional improvement. Of course, we will recognise teachers for their efforts. We have restructured and improved the terms of service and promotion and advancement prospects. Just to give Members an example:- since February 1995, in four promotion exercises, some 16,000 teachers and principals have been promoted.

    A thinking school also provides novel solutions to problems they face over a wide range of issues. Every school is unique in its own way. It has got a slightly different pupil profile, different inclinations and needs, a different school culture, different strengths and weaknesses. So each school, guided by the principal, together with all the teachers will have to tailor their own solutions to school problems and decide on how best to integrate new programmes into the school.

    Schools also have to get together to share their experiences and hence this is one of the main motivating factors for introducing the school cluster programme. We will consider whether to put autonomous schools and independent schools into a cluster so that they can share the experiences and the ideas that they have.

Column: 1408



    We will give these clusters extra resources and greater freedom of action. We will encourage them to work together, share ideas and try things that they could not do previously on their own. In the coming years, as we get more experience with the clusters, we will devolve more authority and freedom of action to them.

    The role of the Ministry of Education also has to change. For the Ministry to support thinking schools, the Ministry itself will have to be a learning organisation. At the systems level, the Ministry will do what individual teachers and schools are doing, which is to challenge traditional principles and practices, studying the changing educational needs of the nation, chart general directions for the service and provide guidelines to mould the education system. The Ministry's role is to set the overall policy, set out the educational objectives and standards to be achieved, and provide the schools, the principals and the teachers, with the resources to get the job done. Thinking schools will generate many good ideas. The Ministry will facilitate the sharing of ideas across schools so that the best teaching and school management practices can be shared. We will do things like setting up websites and so on so that teachers can easily talk to each other and share their ideas.

    We will also encourage the various professional associations of teachers, for example, the science teachers or the geography teachers, to form stronger associations so that they can get together and share their ideas. We want to tap the creativity and energy of all of our 23,000 education officers to come up with new ideas, to share them, to test them, to devise new programmes and practices, and extend and apply them in all our schools in a continuing process of learning, improvement and change. When this happens, thinking schools will drive our education system in high gear into the 21st century.

    As the Prime Minister has said, the future will be one of change, not change to a known fixed state, but change as an ongoing state of things. To prepare for the next generation, education will also have

Column: 1409

to be in a state of continual improvement. Education must stay ahead of this change. Education will mould the future of our nation. If Singapore is to become a learning nation, we will have to begin in our schools. When our young enter into the workforce and take on responsibilities in society, they will carry with them the values and skills that will enable each one of them to strive for excellence in the way they contribute to the nation. Our thinking schools will lay the foundation for a culture of learning in Singapore society. Then will we be able to have a learning nation.

    I believe that I have answered in a general way many of the points that Members have brought up about thinking schools. So I will move on to the subject of National Education.

    For National Education, Dr Ker and Mr Low Thia Khiang have raised a number of concerns about what will be taught and how will it be taught in our schools. The basis for National Education is factual. We will proceed on the basis of fact, not on the basis of consensus of what might appear to be the right interpretation of events, but we will try and proceed on the basis of fact, documented wherever possible. I think this is the most reasonable and best way to proceed with National Education in our schools. There will be a formal and an informal curriculum for the conduct of National Education. Many of the ideas that Members have brought up about including the various activities in National Education will be taken up in the informal curriculum, such as involving students and the schools in community activities and experiential type of activities. These are all very good ideas. These activities are now proceeding already in our schools.

    In the curriculum, we will also include National Education. This will take some time because we have to re-write the syllabus and we will have to change some subjects before we can introduce them in the schools. This part of National Education in the formal curriculum will

Column: 1410

be rolled out over the next few years. So teachers should not be concerned or overly worried that National Education will be an add-on to what is already happening in the schools because we integrate it into subjects.

    As regards National Education examinations, yes, we will expect foreign students in our system to take the National Education examinations because I think it is quite reasonable, ie, foreign students come to Singapore to study and they should understand something about our history, our nation, our aspirations and our goals. This is quite reasonable. If you were to study abroad, say, in the US, I think you would also be studying American history and the American political system and so on. So this is not an unreasonable requirement and is not a particularly onerous requirement.

    On the National Anthem, Mr Chew Heng Ching and Mr Goh Choon Kang have spoken on teaching the students about what the National Anthem means. I totally agree with them. In fact, we do teach our students, both in the primary schools and secondary schools, about the National Anthem, what it means and so on. Obviously, we have to do a better job at it and we will try and do our best. I would like to thank Mr Chew for helping us in this effort today.

    I believe I have addressed most of the questions. There are one or two other issues, like the one Mr Peh raised on technical education and special education. I would appreciate it if we leave them to a little later and I will deal with them when we come to technical education.

in the developed countries offer scholarship with no service bond attached, thereby attracting many young bright scholars, including ours, to take up the offers.

Column: 1412



     Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, first of all, I would like to thank the Minister for the most thoughtful reply to the various questions raised under the thinking schools. I must say that the implementation of thinking schools is indeed in good hands. And since the Minister also asks for new ideas, I would like to throw up some ideas for consideration.

    Sir, imagine there is a lizard up there, at the top right-hand corner, and this lizard wants to move to the bottom left-hand corner over there. This lizard is wondering what is the shortest path from here to there.

    This lizard remembers what he learned in school - that the shortest distance between any two points is a straight line. Since the lizard cannot fly, so what he does is to move along the edge, all the way from the top there to the bottom there, and then diagonally across this chamber floor and gets over there.

    Now the question is: is that the shortest distance between these two points? At first glance, the lizard would appear to be doing the right thing, from up there to down there, to over there. These are straight lines. But if we were now to look at this problem differently, let us remove the roof of this Chamber, and then unfold the four walls of this Chamber, like a shoe box, into a flat plane, and then draw a straight line between this starting point and that ending point, we can see very clearly that the shortest path is not from up there to down there, to over there, but actually from up there, to somewhere to the right side of the Speaker's seat, and then from there to over there.

    Sir, I use this example to illustrate the point that in real life, it is not a question of how well we can remember what we learned in school but of how effective we are in applying what we learned in school to real life environment.

    The Minister mentioned earlier that for Singapore to succeed in future, we need to have more innovators. But what is innovation? Many people equate innovation as being equal to creativity. I do not think so. Because to come out with an innovation, having the creative ideas is only part of

Column: 1413

the solution, because we need to have the technical competency to turn that creative idea into something real. So being innovative means that the students have to be able to come up with new and creative ideas as well as the sound knowledge and adaptable mind to be able to apply the knowledge to the real world.

    In this example I have just quoted, what the students have to be trained is more than just two-dimensional theory. They have to learn how to convert a three-dimensional situation into a two-dimensional problem, and then apply a two-dimensional theory to come up with a solution which is applicable to the three-dimensional world we live in. So it is fairly complicated.

I think what is even more important is to make sure that the process of teaching, the process of rewarding the students, must actually encourage in them the creative mind of applying dead knowledge in a lively manner. This is just a suggestion, Sir.

decided that there would be greater requirement of scientists and engineers in the future.
